title: Peter Persons
text:
Peter Taylor Persons (born September 8, 1962) is an American <a href="professional%20golfer">professional golfer</a> who has played on the <a href="PGA%20Tour">PGA Tour</a> and the <a href="Nationwide%20Tour">Nationwide Tour</a>.
Persons was born and raised in <a href="Macon%2C%20Georgia">Macon, Georgia</a>. He received coaching and training in the junior program developed by Georgia Golf Hall of Fame member Dan Nyimicz at Idle Hour Golf Club in Macon. Persons won the 1980 Georgia Junior Championship and was the runner-up to <a href="Sam%20Randolph">Sam Randolph</a> at the 1985 <a href="United%20States%20Amateur%20Championship%20%28men%27s%20golf%29">U.S. Amateur</a>. He was the 1984–1985 Georgia Golf Association Men's Player of the Year. He attended the <a href="University%20of%20Georgia">University of Georgia</a> and was a member of the <a href="golf">golf</a> team. He turned professional in 1986.
Persons played in a limited number of PGA Tour events in the 1980s. He played full-time on the elite Tour from 1990–1993; and on the Nike Tour (now called the Nationwide Tour) from 1994–1996. His best year in professional golf was 1990; he had a win at the <a href="Chattanooga%20Classic%20%28PGA%20Tour%29">Chattanooga Classic</a>, a T-6 at the <a href="Hawaiian%20Open">Hawaiian Open</a>, and finished 66th on the final money list that year. At the 1990 Chattanooga Classic, he finished at 20-under-par 260 to defeat <a href="Richard%20Zokol">Richard Zokol</a> by two strokes. The tournament was held the same week as the <a href="NEC%20World%20Series%20of%20Golf">NEC World Series of Golf</a> where most of the Tour's top-tier players elected to compete.
Results in major championships.
"Note: Persons never played in <a href="The%20Open%20Championship">The Open Championship</a>."<br>
CUT = missed the half-way cut<br>
"T" = tied
